'''Michael Wilson Hardy''' (born September 13, 1990), known professionally as '''HARDY''' (stylized in [[all caps]]), is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. He has written songs for [[Florida Georgia Line]], [[Chris Lane]], [[Blake Shelton]], [[Dallas Smith]], [[Thomas Rhett]], and [[Morgan Wallen]]. He released his debut album ''[[A Rock]]'' for [[Big Loud|Big Loud Records]], as well as the mixtape ''[[Hixtape, Vol. 1]].'' His singles "[[Give Heaven Some Hell]]", "[[One Beer (Hardy song)|One Beer]]", "[[Wait in the Truck]]" and "[[Truck Bed (song)|Truck Bed]]" charted in the US and Canada and he was featured on the Dallas Smith song "[[Some Things Never Change (Dallas Smith song)|Some Things Never Change]]". His album, ''[[The Mockingbird & the Crow]]'', topped the country music charts in early 2023.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/country-albums/2023-02-04/ | title=Top Country Albums | magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] }}</ref>

==Early life==
Michael Wilson Hardy was born to Mike and Sarah Hardy, in [[Philadelphia, Mississippi]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Hawkins |first=Scott |title=Hardy coming home to headline Fair |url=https://neshobademocrat.com/stories/hardy-coming-home-to-headline-fair,50937 |access-date=2022-03-29 |website=The Neshoba Democrat |date=21 July 2021 |language=en}}</ref> Growing up, Hardy often listened to music with his father, whom he has cited as the source of some of his earliest and fondest memories.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Ceneviva |first=Alex |date=2021-10-20 |title=The Untold Truth Of Hardy |url=https://www.nickiswift.com/638369/the-untold-truth-of-hardy/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=NickiSwift.com |language=en-US}}</ref> 

He attended Neshoba Central High School in Philadelphia, Mississippi. It was during that time that he wrote his first song to "impress a girl."<ref name=":0"/> Hardy then went on to attend [[Middle Tennessee State University]], where he got a degree in songwriting in the Recording Industry Management program.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2021-11-22 |title=Meet Country Singer Hardy: "Nashville's most clever new redneck songwriter" |url=https://www.countrythangdaily.com/hardy-country-singer/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |language=en-US}}</ref>

After graduating, Hardy took a trip to visit his sister, in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], which led to the start of his career. While there, he realized that it was possible to make [[country music]] into a career.<ref name=":0"/> Hardy met [[Florida Georgia Line]] in 2012 at a party where he was introduced to them by a mutual acquaintance.<ref name=":03">{{Cite web |last=Ceneviva |first=Alex |date=2021-10-20 |title=The Untold Truth Of HARDY |url=https://www.nickiswift.com/638369/the-untold-truth-of-hardy/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=NickiSwift.com |language=en-US}}</ref> He was eventually reconnected with the group years later.

After moving to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue songwriting, he became a writing partner of the duo [[Florida Georgia Line]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/who-is-hardy/ | title=Who is Hardy? 5 things you need to know | work=The Boot | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> Among the songs that Hardy wrote include "[[Up Down (Morgan Wallen song)|Up Down]]" by [[Morgan Wallen]]. Following the song's success and encouragement from record producer [[Joey Moi]], Hardy was signed to [[Big Loud|Big Loud Records]] in 2018.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://theboot.com/michael-hardy-songwriter-country-singer/ | title=Hardy talks going from songwriter to artist | work=The Boot | date=14 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref>

== Career ==
In October 2018, he released an EP titled ''This Ole Boy'', which he promoted by joining Wallen's If I Know Me Tour.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2018/10/hardy-releases-debut-ep-today/ | title=Hardy releases debut EP today | work=[[MusicRow]] | date=19 October 2018 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> This was followed in 2019 by the single "Rednecker",<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/who-is-hardy/ | title=5 things to know about Hardy, country's newest redneck | work=Taste of Country | date=18 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> and a second EP titled ''Where to Find Me''. To support the EP, Hardy joined Florida Georgia Line on their [[Can't Say I Ain't Country Tour]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/hardy-wheretofindme-ep/ | title=Hardy to debut four new tracks on 'Where to Find Me' EP | work=Sounds Like Nashville | date=18 January 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref>

Hardy also co-wrote Florida Georgia Line's singles "[[Simple (Florida Georgia Line song)|Simple]]" and "[[Talk You Out of It]]", Blake Shelton's singles "[[God's Country (Blake Shelton song)|God's Country]]"<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/hardy-interview-rednecker-florida-georgia-line/ | title=How Hardy is turning songwriting success into an artist's career | work=Taste of Country | date=March 2019 | access-date=April 2, 2019}}</ref> and "[[Hell Right]]", "[[Drop (Dallas Smith song)|Drop]]" by [[Dallas Smith]], [[Chris Lane]]'s single "[[I Don't Know About You]]", and [[Jameson Rodgers]]' debut single "[[Some Girls (Jameson Rodgers song)|Some Girls]]".<ref name="casey">{{cite web | url=http://www.nashcountrydaily.com/2019/09/12/hardys-new-hixtape-vol-1-features-17-guest-artists-including-keith-urban-thomas-rhett-dustin-lynch-more/ | title=Hardy's New "Hixtape Vol. 1" Features 17 Guest Artists, Including Keith Urban, Thomas Rhett, Dustin Lynch & More | work=Nash Country Daily | date=September 12, 2019 | access-date=September 13, 2019 | last=Casey| first=Jim}}</ref>

In September 2019, Hardy released a collaborative mixtape titled ''Hixtape, Vol. 1'',<ref name="casey"/> which featured a total of 17 artists including [[Thomas Rhett]], [[Keith Urban]], [[Tracy Lawrence]], [[Jake Owen]], [[Trace Adkins]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Zakk Wylde]], [[Cole Swindell]], [[Dustin Lynch]], and [[Morgan Wallen]].

Hardy was set to be on tour with [[Thomas Rhett]] in 2020 for Rhett's [[Center Point Road Tour]], but the tour was postponed due to the [[COVID-19 pandemic]]. In September 2020, Hardy released his debut album ''[[A Rock]]'', which included his single "[[One Beer (Hardy song)|One Beer]]".<ref>{{cite magazine|title=How Hardy Became Nashville's Most Clever New Redneck Songwriter|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/hardy-new-album-a-rock-1031836/|first=Jon|last=Freeman|date=July 21, 2020|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=September 21, 2020}}</ref> He was also featured on [[Dallas Smith]]'s single "[[Some Things Never Change (Dallas Smith song)|Some Things Never Change]]".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mitz |first1=Roman |title=Dallas Smith – Country Music Awards Continue To 'Drop' |url=https://themusicexpress.ca/dallas-smith-country-music-awards-continue-to-drop/ |access-date=October 22, 2020 |work=The Music Express |date=September 28, 2020}}</ref> In June 2021, he was featured on the [[Brantley Gilbert]] single "[[The Worst Country Song of All Time]]". In July 2021, he was featured on [[Dierks Bentley]]'s single "[[Beers on Me]]", which he co-wrote.<ref>{{cite web|first=Chris|last=Parton|title=Brantley Gilbert, Toby Keith and Hardy Team For 'The Worst Country Song'|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/music/brantley-gilbert-toby-keith-hardy-worst-country-song/|date=18 June 2021|work=Sounds Like Nashville}}</ref>
[[File:Hardy at a concert in 2019.jpg|upright=0.85|thumb|Hardy performing in 2019]]
He later toured with Sean Stemaly in 2021 and created ''Hixtape, Vol. 2''. This album included artists such as [[Matt Stell]], [[Jon Pardi]], [[Jimmie Allen]], [[Colt Ford]], [[Randy Houser]], [[Rhett Akins]], and [[Lainey Wilson]]. In the fall of 2021, Hardy went on tour with [[Jason Aldean]], as well. The "Back in the Saddle" tour kicked off in August 2021, and included [[Lainey Wilson]], in addition to Hardy.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Bosch |first=Christina |date=2021-10-21 |title=Jason Aldean Announces Tour with Hardy & Lainey Wilson |url=https://www.thenashnews.com/2021/10/21/jason-aldean-announces-tour-with-hardy-lainey-wilson/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=The Nash News |language=en-US |archive-date=2022-02-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220217012146/https://www.thenashnews.com/2021/10/21/jason-aldean-announces-tour-with-hardy-lainey-wilson/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>

[[Morgan Wallen]] announced his plans for his 2022 ''Dangerous'' tour, which included Hardy for almost all of the nearly 50 stops, including stops in Pennsylvania, South Carolina, Georgia, Louisiana, Oklahoma, and South Dakota.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Dukes |first=Billy|title=BREAKING: Morgan Wallen Announces the Dangerous Tour — See Dates! |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/morgan-wallen-the-dangerous-tour-dates-2022/ |access-date=2022-03-04 |website=Taste of Country |language=en}}</ref>

In October 2022, Hardy announced that his album, ''The Mockingbird & the Crow'', would be released on January 20, 2023, via Big Loud Records with guest vocals from fellow country singers [[Morgan Wallen]] and [[Lainey Wilson]] and [[A Day to Remember]] lead singer [[Jeremy McKinnon]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Nicholson|first=Jessica|title=HARDY Is Releasing a Half Country, Half Rock Album|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/hardy-announces-new-album-tracklist-morgan-wallen-feature-1235153334/|date=October 10, 2022|access-date=October 10, 2022|magazine=Billboard}}</ref> 

Hardy released three songs from ''[[The Mockingbird & the Crow]]'' on October 9, 2022: "Truck Bed", "Here Lies Country Music", and "The Mockingbird & the Crow". The full album features half country and half rock music. The first half of the album is more traditional country music with all the song titles stylized in lower case. The song "The Mockingbird & the Crow" features a distinct shift halfway through the song to the rock genre, and the rest of the album continues as rock and hard rock, though still using country themes and imagery in the lyrics. The rock song titles are all stylized in uppercase.

In early 2024, Hardy announced a collaborative project titled ''[[Hixtape: Vol. 3: Difftape]]'', featuring him and other artists covering songs by [[Joe Diffie]] and honoring the fourth anniversary of his death in 2020. Unlike the previous two ''Hixtape'' installments, it is not credited solely as a Hardy album.<ref>https://musicrow.com/2024/03/hixtape-vol-3-difftape-reimagines-joe-diffie-classics-with-special-collaborations/</ref>

== Awards ==
In 2019, Hardy received his first nomination for the [[Country Music Association]] awards. Held at the [[Bridgestone Arena]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], Hardy was nominated for Song of the Year for Blake Shelton's "God's Country", which Hardy co-wrote with [[Devin Dawson]] and [[Jordan Schmidt]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Whitaker |first=Sterling|title=Here's a Full List of the 2019 CMA Awards Nominees |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/2019-cma-awards-nominees/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |website=Taste of Country |date=13 November 2019 |language=en}}</ref> He was then again nominated in the [[55th Annual Country Music Association Awards|2021 CMA Awards]] as New Artist of the Year.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Freeman |first=Jon |date=2021-09-09 |title=2021 CMA Awards Nominations: Chris Stapleton, Eric Church Are Top Nominees |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/2021-cma-awards-nominees-nominations-1222399/ |access-date=2022-04-21 |magazine=Rolling Stone |language=en-US}}</ref> 

Hardy was nominated for two awards in the 2020 [[Academy of Country Music]] Awards: Song of the Year, for [[Blake Shelton|Blake Shelton's]] "Gods Country" that Hardy co-wrote, and Songwriter of the Year. Following that, in 2021, he received three nominations: New Male Artist, Songwriter of the Year, and Music Event of the Year, for his song "One Beer" along with [[Lauren Alaina]] and [[Devin Dawson]]. Hardy was nominated for two awards in the 2022 [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], held at the [[Allegiant Stadium]] in Las Vegas. He did not win the award for New Male Artist, losing to Parker McCollum. He was, however, named the Academy of Country Music's 2022 Songwriter of the Year, making that his first ACM Award.  During the 2023 ACA Awards, Hardy was nominated for multiple awards, of which he ended up taking home three.  His colabration with Lainey Wilson won for "Best Visual Media of the Year" and "Musical Event of the Year".  In addition, he ended up winning the Artist-Songwriter of the Year".<ref>{{Citation |title=Academy of Country Music Awards |date=2022-03-08 |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Country_Music_Awards&oldid=1075984700 |work=Wikipedia |language=en |access-date=2022-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-08 |title=Country star Hardy reveals shocking win during ACM Awards red carpet |url=https://www.hellomagazine.com/celebrities/20220308134827/acm-awards-hardy-shocking-las-vegas-win/ |access-date=2022-03-11 |website=HELLO! |language=en}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
Hardy proposed to his girlfriend Caleigh Ryan in August 2021 at The Lyric in [[Oxford, Mississippi]] which is where the couple met in 2017. The two married on October 29, 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Fisher|first=Kelly|date=August 25, 2021|title=Hardy Tells The Sweet Story Of How He Proposed To wife Caleigh Ryan Hardy|url=https://www.iheart.com/content/2021-08-25-hardy-tells-the-sweet-story-of-how-he-proposed-to-now-fianc-caleigh-ryan/|access-date=February 17, 2021|website=iHeart|language=en}}</ref>
